messages.subject: commercial message
messages.msgSnippet: All, in my quest to better my collection, move almost totally out of the Edo period and into the Muromachi period, I am going to offer one of my better tsuba,
messages.messageBody:
All, in my quest to better my collection, move almost totally out of the
Edo period and into the Muromachi period, I am going to offer one of my
better tsuba, a Shimizu Jingo up for sale. It is a very nice guard. All
information is available from the link below. It has hakogaki by
Torigoye, is published in Tsuba Kanshoki (2nd edition) by Torigoye and
has NTHK kanteisho.

http://www.nihontokanjipages.com/personal/collection/jingo.html

Asking price is US$3000.00
Price will include EMS shipping anywhere in the world.

This is an excellent tsuba in wonderful condition and is one for the
serious collector.

Inquiries can be made to me at ikkanshi@...
<mailto:ikkanshi@...>

Cheers

Richard



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)
messages.msgSnippet: Choshu and Bushu Ito used both nunome and dot-type inlay, as did Kyo-shoami. Don t get too confused about Omori in this context -- they have nothing to do
messages.messageBody:
Choshu and Bushu Ito used both nunome and "dot-type" inlay, as did Kyo-shoami.

Don't get too confused about Omori in this context -- they have nothing to do with iron sukashi. Certainly worth looking into as one of the major machibori kinko groups, though.

Jim

http://www.jimgilbertphoto.com/


----- Original Message -----
From: Kenneth Wilson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, February 01, 2008 8:19 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)


Hey Rich, Michael, Michel et al,

I was thinking Choshu but how often did they do inlays? Is this too broad a question for sukashi schools, but which ones did inlay work? I only started thinking shaomi because of this, but I really don't know enough about which schools did inlay in their sukashi work. The little dots of inlay just kind of reminded of shoami but I know that isn't a lot to go by. And as I was reading the KTK supplement catalog just now, a comment on ko-shoami was they have a feeling of movement that this piece has at least to me. Not that I think it is that old. Also any comments on the weld displayed in the second photo, it looks a little more obvious or some metal was added to bond the goose to the mimi? I am going to read about Omari. I am in a learning mode at the moment. Thanks.
Ken

----- Original Message ----
From: Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, February 1, 2008 7:30:35 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)

I was thinking early Chosh√ª. I was going back to look at the books again

but that was my first impression. Maybe around the 1700's or some time.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)
messages.msgSnippet: As far as I can recall, this style of work was first done in Kyoto by the Shoami.  Certainly it was later adopted by many other groups around the country and
messages.messageBody:
As far as I can recall, this style of work was first done in Kyoto by the Shoami. Certainly it was later adopted by many other groups around the country and some of those like Ito, Choshu and Kinai were bigger producers in the mid to late Edo period. Probably in some cases the work of those groups can be confused, but the iron, carving and inlay work tend to be a bit different.

Jim






Jim - My fault for citing Hamilton - you are of course right and have
pointed this out in past...I do like the tsuba pictured at the bottom
of plate cited for being similar in treatment of the birds, rim, and
negative space.

I'm interested to read the comparison of Milt's tsuba with the initial
example.

The range of Shoami work being so broad, and my expectation that this
is 1700s or later has me wonder if like many Shoami attributed pieces,
that it follows the work of another school...Comments?

Michael

http://www.satcho.com Specialists in books related to the study &
appreciation of the Japanese sword as art.
_______________________________________________

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "bungotakadasword"
<MuramasaIII@...> wrote:
>
> a signed example of Shoami......
>
> http://www.esnips.com/web/tsuba?docsPage=15#files
>
> milt
>

messages.msgSnippet: sorry all, that was pretty poorly written. I was in a hurry. The seppa dai appears to be too narrow for Choshu and looks more Kyo is what I meant to say. and,
messages.messageBody:
sorry all, that was pretty poorly written. I was in a hurry.

The seppa dai appears to be too narrow for Choshu and looks more Kyo is
what I meant to say.

and, there are many Chosh√ª works that have inlay and other decorations
is what I should have written.

Too mush to do, so little time.

Richard

messages.msgSnippet: Omori is completely off. I agree with Jim on Kyo-Shoami, which was also my first inclination. Gordon
messages.messageBody:
Omori is completely off. I agree with Jim on Kyo-Shoami, which was also my first
inclination.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [SPAM] Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)
messages.msgSnippet: Yes, probably the best call Jim. My first shot kantei is always a bity off :-), I shoudl ahve looked a bity longer. The seppa dai also is a little more narrow
messages.messageBody:
Yes, probably the best call Jim. My first shot kantei is always a bity
off :-), I shoudl ahve looked a bity longer. The seppa dai also is a
little more narrow than Chosh√ª.

I just saw Ken's post and many Chosh√ª works has inlay. it was quite
common. When I get a moment, I will cite some examples.

Rich

Jim Gilbert wrote:
>
> The attributions in the Peabody catalog aren't reliable. Choshu is a
> reasonable call, but given the iron, narrow hitsuana and the style of
> carving I'd probably go with Kyo-shoami based on what I can see in the
> photos.
>
> Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)
messages.msgSnippet: Hey Rich, Michael, Michel et al, I was thinking Choshu but how often did they do inlays?  Is this too broad a question for sukashi schools, but which ones did
messages.messageBody:
Hey Rich, Michael, Michel et al,

I was thinking Choshu but how often did they do inlays? Is this too broad a question for sukashi schools, but which ones did inlay work? I only started thinking shaomi because of this, but I really don't know enough about which schools did inlay in their sukashi work. The little dots of inlay just kind of reminded of shoami but I know that isn't a lot to go by. And as I was reading the KTK supplement catalog just now, a comment on ko-shoami was they have a feeling of movement that this piece has at least to me. Not that I think it is that old. Also any comments on the weld displayed in the second photo, it looks a little more obvious or some metal was added to bond the goose to the mimi? I am going to read about Omari. I am in a learning mode at the moment. Thanks.
Ken

----- Original Message ----
From: Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, February 1, 2008 7:30:35 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)














I was thinking early Chosh√ª. I was going back to look at the books again

but that was my first impression. Maybe around the 1700's or some time.



Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)
messages.msgSnippet: The attributions in the Peabody catalog aren t reliable.  Choshu is a reasonable call, but given the iron, narrow hitsuana and the style of carving I d
messages.messageBody:
The attributions in the Peabody catalog aren't reliable. Choshu is a reasonable call, but given the iron, narrow hitsuana and the style of carving I'd probably go with Kyo-shoami based on what I can see in the photos.

Jim


----- Original Message -----
From: Richard Turner
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, February 01, 2008 7:30 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)


I was thinking early Chosh√ª. I was going back to look at the books again
but that was my first impression. Maybe around the 1700's or some time.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: Help needed for identification ( new trial)
messages.msgSnippet: Try Omori school. The Peabody Museum catalog (Hamilton, 1975) has two tsuba attributed to this school on plate 17 that look similar. Michael
messages.messageBody:
Try Omori school.

The Peabody Museum catalog (Hamilton, 1975) has two tsuba attributed
to this school on plate 17 that look similar.



Michael

http://www.satcho.com Specialists in books related to the study &
appreciation of the Japanese sword as art.

messages.subject: Help needed for identification ( new trial)
messages.msgSnippet: Dear all,   Can somebody give me some hints for identifying this tsuba - I have seen a similar enough one  ( ie geese, weeds, water) in early 20th century
messages.messageBody:
Dear all, Can somebody give me some hints for identifying this tsuba -
I have seen a similar enough one ( ie geese, weeds, water) in early
20th century french auction catalogs ( however picture without any
description). Diameter 80mm - some incrustations ( yellow metal on
geese eyes and white metal dots on weeds leaves and water) - link to MCu
photo album below Thanks for help Michel Cuni
see photos
<http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/b971>



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
